utterances: We're taking your calls this hour at 1 (800) 989-8255.
Lynn is on the line from Truckee, California.
Hi, Lynn.
Hi.
How are you?
Good.
I retired actually in my late--well, mid-late 40s and I'm now 54 and I've been in Truckee for almost eight years.
But--and I initially picked Truckee because I wanted mountains and cross-country skiing and trails to run and stuff like that, but I'm finding Truckee somewhat intellectually empty.
And so I'm thinking in a few years I will probably move to a town with a university or at least a research institute, but again another small town.
I'm thinking maybe Santa Fe or a place like that.
Hmm.
How many people--thank you for your call, Lynn.
How many people change, you know, go to a completely different kind of community or do you think will look for a complete change in lifestyle?
You know, it's a great question, Frank, but I think for our grandparents, they kind of grew up and passed away within probably 10 miles of their childhood.
Yeah.
And then our moms and dads may have moved a little bit and maybe even taken that big jump to move to a different town in retirement.
Again, the boomers are just so much less likely to be anchored down.
They have--and by the way, the biggest gold rush right now in housing for this new generation are these time shares.
So you can spend three months in Cabo San Lucas and three months in Lake Tahoe and three months in Manhattan, which is really kind of the penultimate of not having any one location.
But this is a generation, just like Lynn has mentioned, who, if they don't like...
Yeah.

...you know, the way it is right now, they'll do some homework and maybe gather up some friends and, by the way, maybe even move with a group of friends and buy a house together and start a new life that'll match their new appetites and interests.
Well--and it also raises the question, Ken, of niche communities.
Florida may have some competition as a retirement destination, but there are other ways of making your place desirable and one tactic is the growing niche retirement community.
Gina Razete is a land developer and a builder.
She and her partner created two gay and lesbian retirement communities, one in southwest Florida, the other outside of Boone, North Carolina, called Carefree Cove.
They're getting ready to start a third one and Gina joins us on the line from Orlando, Florida, where she's attending a gathering of the homebuilders association.
Gina, thanks for joining us.
Hi, Frank.
How are you today?
I'm doing very well.
Tell me when you...
Good.
...decided to build the first gay and lesbian retirement community?
Well, we decided back in '94 to create our company and start developing just for this community.
We knew that there was a niche that needed to be filled.
This market is desirous of living in the same location with each other so that they could share that lifestyle without having any ramifications of it.
What are your customers looking for?
What do you think they're looking for?
They're looking for the same thing any other baby boomer is: the nice house, nice location, safe--everything that the baby boomers are looking for, but also the added amenities.
Definitely want to have social areas that they can get together and have parties and a lot of amenities, like with the walking trails and the exercise rooms.
Fitness is very important to my customers.
So it's very typical of baby boomers and not so much golf, though; although I do have a lot of customers that play golf.
But I don't think that it is such a big thing for them to have the big golf course.
But, you know, it does against one of the trends we've heard, and that is people who want to make sure that they are staying in diverse communities.
They don't want to go into, they're saying, old-age retirement places like their parents, but in this case it's people who want to be among people like them.
You're going to see acreage for people who just love to garden.
You're going to see artists communes.
You're going to see Zen seekers forming into their own communities.
Retired military, by the way, have already built communities...
Sure.
That's right.
It's a lifestyle.
And you'll find lifestyle niche communities of many different things, not just gay and lesbian, but all different kind of interests also are out there.
Homebuilders association having a huge convention this week and I've been to many seminars.
People are doing a lot of research into any way that you can be unique in the home-building or the land development industry.
And one of the ways is to find these little niche markets of lifestyle communities.
Well, Gina, stay with us.
I've got a few more questions for you and for Ken Dychtwald.
You bet.
And we're going to continue to talk about the aging boomer population, where we are all going to go when we retire.
That's our conversation today.
I'm Frank Stasio.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Announcements)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Frank Stasio sitting in for Neal Conan.

Tomorrow on this program, diabetes, one of the nation's biggest medical problems, so much so that New York City is taking a controversial step of tracking the blood sugar levels of diabetic residents.
Why diabetes has become so common and what individuals and communities are doing to cope.
That is tomorrow on TALK OF THE NATION.
Today we're talking about the aging baby boom population and where they're retiring.
We're talking to Gina Razete, who is a land developer and builder.
She and a partner have created two gay and lesbian retirement communities, one in southwest Florida, the other outside Boone, North Carolina.
And, Gina, I know that you're reluctant to talk in too particular detail about the southwest--about the Florida community.
Is there--I mean, are you sort of in a quandary here about how much you want folks, the neighbors, to know and then how you have to get the word out to gay and lesbian buyers?
Yes, it's always been a quandary.
That is true.

However, one thing we've found is that once people know how wonderful neighbors you are and that you bring property values up and that you're great neighbors and good for the community, really get involved in the community, give a lot back, they are happy to have you around.
We, as developers, hire local trade people for everything that we do.

And we want to make sure that the local community is getting all of the economic benefit of our coming to their community to develop and for all the residents coming in, the economic benefits that come from...
Have you ever gotten complaints from the surrounding community?
Never.
And how about...
Isn't that great?
That sounds like great news.
How about the folks who live there?
Have they had any sense of being harassed or any of that?
Not at all.
Really wonderful people to live around in all of our communities.

And I think the main reason is is because we are really, really good people to be with and to be neighbors of and very--you know, everything nice-looking, well-maintained, very good-looking communities we build.
In my own humble opinion, we happen to build extremely nice communities at Carefree communities.
What are some of the other niches that folks are talking about down there at the homebuilders convention?
Oh, there's--you know, I've heard of everything from football fans of certain colleges.
I think Iowa State or something...
Eww.
They got together and did a little development.
I've--you know, you've often heard of different church groups having--Protestants getting together and having their own communities for mostly assisted living probably or apartment buildings.
I know of one in southwest Florida.
All right.
There are so many niches...
Frank...
Yeah?
...and you can appeal in your marketing to any of those niches and--people who enjoy a certain golfer or a golf course designer...
Have a whole development just for them.
The...
Yes...
